body_text:
South Stack Lighthouse was built on Holy Island, off the Isle of Anglesey, by Daniel Alexandra (engineer) and Joseph Nelson (builder) during 1808-1809.

The build was initiated by Captain Hugh Evans who was determined to have a lighthouse constructed after collecting facts and figures regarding maritime disasters on the Holy Island coastline and presenting them to the decision-makers of the time in 1807. The build of this now famous 27.7 metre tall South Stack lighthouse was subsequently commissioned on the 30-metre summit of this rocky outcrop.

As would be expected the weather hindered the operation on many occasions. To add spice to the build men and materials had to be swung down a rope sliding basket onto the island. Indeed it wasn’t until 1828 that a connecting iron suspension bridge was built at a cost in excess of £1000.

The construction of this magnificent lighthouse must have been very demanding, technically challenging and extremely dangerous for the builders of the day.

Please take a moment to watch this short video and imagine arriving at South Stack on a beautiful, calm summer’s evening:
